title: Why you procrastinate even when it feels bad

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.text: In the city-states of Mesopotamia

title: The last chief of the Comanches and the fall of an empire - Dustin Tahmahkera

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the conflict between the Comanches and the United States forces in the Texas frontier?

options.label: A
options.text: The Comanches were trying to expand their territory.

options.label: B
options.text: The United States forces were trying to steal Comanche lands for white settlers.

options.label: C
options.text: The Comanches were resisting the spread of Christianity.

options.label: D
options.text: The United States forces were trying to impose their language on the Comanches.

multiple-choice.question: What was unique about the Comanche Empire?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a unified group under central control.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a number of bands, each with its own leaders.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a matriarchal society.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a nomadic society.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Quanah Parker's leadership?

options.label: A
options.text: He led the Comanches to victory against the United States forces.

options.label: B
options.text: He negotiated a treaty that established the Comanche reservation.

options.label: C
options.text: He adapted to changing circumstances and led the Comanches to survive and thrive.

options.label: D
options.text: He resisted the use of peyote in the Native American Church.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the buffalo hide market on the Comanches?

options.label: A
options.text: It provided a new source of income for the Comanches.

options.label: B
options.text: It led to the slaughter of millions of buffalo, threatening the Comanches' way of life.

options.label: C
options.text: It had no significant impact on the Comanches.

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the Comanches' relocation to a new reservation.

multiple-choice.question: What was Quanah Parker's role in the Comanche Nation after his surrender?

options.label: A
options.text: He became a farmer and abandoned his traditional way of life.

options.label: B
options.text: He became a leader and advocate for the Comanches, securing better rations and advocating for schools and houses.

options.label: C
options.text: He became a recluse and had no involvement in Comanche affairs.

options.label: D
options.text: He became a warrior and continued to fight against the United States forces.

title: History through the eyes of the potato - Leo Bear-McGuinness

multiple-choice.question: Where were potatoes first cultivated around 8,000 years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: Ancient Europe

options.label: B
options.text: Ancient Peru

options.label: C
options.text: Ancient China

options.label: D
options.text: Ancient Africa

multiple-choice.question: Why did Europeans initially reject potatoes as a food source?

options.label: A
options.text: They were too expensive to cultivate.

options.label: B
options.text: They were considered too closely related to the deadly nightshade plant belladonna.

options.label: C
options.text: They were not nutritious enough.

options.label: D
options.text: They were not easy to grow.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the widespread adoption of potatoes as a food source in Europe around 1750?

options.label: A
options.text: A significant decrease in population due to disease.

options.label: B
options.text: A steady growth in population due to increased food security.

options.label: C
options.text: A shift from an agricultural to an industrial economy.

options.label: D
options.text: A decline in the power of European empires.

multiple-choice.question: What was the cause of the Irish Potato Famine from 1845 to 1852?

options.label: A
options.text: Over-reliance on grain crops.

options.label: B
options.text: Potato blight disease.

options.label: C
options.text: Economic downturn.

options.label: D
options.text: War.

multiple-choice.question: What was a significant consequence of the Irish Potato Famine?

options.label: A
options.text: The population of Ireland increased dramatically.

options.label: B
options.text: The Industrial Revolution was delayed.

options.label: C
options.text: Over a million Irish citizens starved to death, and 2 million more left their homes behind.

options.label: D
options.text: The British Empire declined in power.

title: The best way to apologize (according to science)

multiple-choice.question: According to researchers, what is the "centerpiece of an apology"?

options.label: A
options.text: Offering a repair or solution

options.label: B
options.text: Understanding and accepting responsibility for your actions

options.label: C
options.text: Making the other person feel better

options.label: D
options.text: Rationalizing your actions

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of clarifying your intentions non-defensively in an apology?

options.label: A
options.text: To shift the blame to the other person

options.label: B
options.text: To make yourself feel better

options.label: C
options.text: To help the other person understand your perspective

options.label: D
options.text: To avoid taking responsibility

multiple-choice.question: What is the "offer of repair" in an apology?

options.label: A
options.text: A verbal commitment to make the same mistake again

options.label: B
options.text: A tangible or symbolic gesture to repair the damage caused by your offense

options.label: C
options.text: A statement that you are not responsible for the mistake

options.label: D
options.text: A promise to forget about the incident

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is a common mistake people make when apologizing?

options.label: A
options.text: Focusing on the other person's perspective

options.label: B
options.text: Rationalizing their actions instead of taking responsibility

options.label: C
options.text: Offering a repair or solution

options.label: D
options.text: Apologizing too quickly

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of an apology, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To get forgiveness and move on

options.label: B
options.text: To express remorse and accept accountability

options.label: C
options.text: To make the other person feel better

options.label: D
options.text: To avoid taking responsibility

title: Does working hard really make you a good person? - Azim Shariff

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is "effort moralization"?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that people who work harder are more competent.

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that people who work harder are more moral.

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that people who work smarter are more moral.

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that people who work less are more moral.

multiple-choice.question: In the study mentioned by the speaker, what was the result when participants were asked about two widget makers, one of whom worked harder to produce the same number of widgets?

options.label: A
options.text: The participants saw the harder-working widget maker as more competent and more moral.

options.label: B
options.text: The participants saw the harder-working widget maker as less competent and less moral.

options.label: C
options.text: The participants saw the harder-working widget maker as less competent but more moral.

options.label: D
options.text: The participants saw the harder-working widget maker as more competent but less moral.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is "workism"?

options.label: A
options.text: A culture that values productivity and efficiency above all else.

options.label: B
options.text: A culture that values hard work and effort above all else, regardless of productivity.

options.label: C
options.text: A culture that values leisure and relaxation above all else.

options.label: D
options.text: A culture that values creativity and innovation above all else.

multiple-choice.question: The speaker mentions a story about a bounty on cobra skins in colonial India. What was the unintended consequence of this bounty?

options.label: A
options.text: The cobra population decreased significantly.

options.label: B
options.text: The cobra population remained the same.

options.label: C
options.text: The cobra population increased significantly.

options.label: D
options.text: The bounty had no impact on the cobra population.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the problem with valuing effort and hard work above all else?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to increased productivity and efficiency.

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to a culture that values meaningful work and productivity.

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to a culture that values effort over productivity and can create perverse incentives.

options.label: D
options.text: It leads to a culture that values leisure and relaxation above all else.

title: Why it‚Äôs so hard to make healthy decisions - David Asch

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the speaker's talk?

options.label: A
options.text: To explain how people make rational decisions about their health

options.label: B
options.text: To discuss the importance of education in changing health behavior

options.label: C
options.text: To highlight the limitations of conventional approaches to human motivation in health care

options.label: D
options.text: To argue that financial incentives are the most effective way to change health behavior

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the problem with conventional approaches to human motivation in health care?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too expensive

options.label: B
options.text: They are too complicated

options.label: C
options.text: They assume that people behave rationally

options.label: D
options.text: They are too time-consuming

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a behavioral reflex that can be used to improve health behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: The desire to avoid regret

options.label: B
options.text: The tendency to overestimate the value of small probabilities

options.label: C
options.text: The instinct to aim at a target (e.g. a fly in a urinal)

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the experiment with the electronic pill bottles and the lottery?

options.label: A
options.text: Patients were less likely to take their medication

options.label: B
options.text: Patients were more likely to take their medication, but only if they won the lottery

options.label: C
options.text: Patients were more likely to take their medication, because they hated the sense of missing out

options.label: D
options.text: There was no significant change in patients' behavior

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is a key principle of behavioral economics?

options.label: A
options.text: That people always behave rationally

options.label: B
options.text: That people are motivated by financial incentives

options.label: C
options.text: That people are irrational, but in predictable ways

options.label: D
options.text: That people are only motivated by social interactions

title: Should you care what your parents think?

multiple-choice.question: What is reactance theory in psychology?

options.label: A
options.text: A motivational state that occurs when people feel their freedom is being threatened.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of behavior that involves ignoring health campaigns.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of romantic relationship that faces parental disapproval.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of social network effect that predicts the success of a romantic relationship.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Romeo and Juliet Effect in psychology?

options.label: A
options.text: A trend where couples who face parental disapproval are more likely to strengthen their relationship.

options.label: B
options.text: A trend where couples who face parental disapproval are more likely to crumble under the pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of reactance that involves impulsively doing the opposite of what one is told.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of social network effect that predicts the success of a romantic relationship.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Social Network Effect in psychology?

options.label: A
options.text: A trend where couples who face parental disapproval are more likely to strengthen their relationship.

options.label: B
options.text: A trend where the long-term success of a romantic relationship can be predicted by the perceived approval or disapproval of the couple's friends and family.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of reactance that involves impulsively doing the opposite of what one is told.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of behavior that involves ignoring health campaigns.

multiple-choice.question: What are the two types of reactance according to psychologists?

options.label: A
options.text: Defiant reactance and independent reactance.

options.label: B
options.text: Positive reactance and negative reactance.

options.label: C
options.text: Impulsive reactance and reflective reactance.

options.label: D
options.text: Emotional reactance and rational reactance.

multiple-choice.question: What can help buffer against disapproval from others in romantic relationships?

options.label: A
options.text: Support from a few close companions.

options.label: B
options.text: Disapproval from friends and family.

options.label: C
options.text: Ignoring health campaigns.

options.label: D
options.text: Impulsive behavior.

title: How do carbohydrates impact your health? - Richard J. Wood

multiple-choice.question: What is the main function of insulin in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: To raise blood sugar levels

options.label: B
options.text: To lower blood sugar levels

options.label: C
options.text: To break down complex carbohydrates

options.label: D
options.text: To synthesize proteins

options.label: A
options.text: Fiber

options.label: B
options.text: Starch

options.label: C
options.text: Oligosaccharides

options.label: D
options.text: Polysaccharides

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the degree to which a unit of insulin lowers blood sugar?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Insulin resistance

options.label: C
options.text: Glycemic index

options.label: D
options.text: Metabolic syndrome

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following foods has a low glycemic index?

options.label: A
options.text: White bread

options.label: B
options.text: Soda

options.label: C
options.text: Vegetables

options.label: D
options.text: Crackers

options.label: A
options.text: Insulin resistance

options.label: B
options.text: Metabolic syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: Type II diabetes

options.label: D

title: How the food you eat affects your gut - Shilpa Ravella

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the gut microbiome in our bodies?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce hormones that regulate our appetite

options.label: B
options.text: To break down food the body can't digest, produce important nutrients, regulate the immune system, and protect against harmful germs

options.label: C
options.text: To absorb nutrients from the food we eat

options.label: D
options.text: To eliminate waste from the body

multiple-choice.question: What type of food is the best fuel for gut bacteria?

options.label: A
options.text: High-fat, meat-heavy foods

options.label: B
options.text: Low-fiber, processed foods

options.label: C
options.text: Dietary fiber from foods like fruits, vegetables, nuts, legumes, and whole grains

options.label: D
options.text: Foods high in dairy fat and sugar-sweetened sodas

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the gut bacteria when we eat low-fiber processed foods?

options.label: A
options.text: They multiply and become more diverse

options.label: B
options.text: They die off due to lack of fuel

options.label: C
options.text: They become more resistant to antibiotics

options.label: D
options.text: They start to feed on the mucus lining of the gut

multiple-choice.question: What type of foods can introduce good bacteria, also known as probiotics, into your gut?

options.label: A
options.text: Fried dishes and processed foods

options.label: B
options.text: Fermented foods like kimchi, sauerkraut, tempeh, and kombucha

options.label: C
options.text: High-fat, meat-heavy foods

options.label: D
options.text: Foods high in dairy fat and sugar-sweetened sodas

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of a diet high in fiber and low in fat on the gut microbiome?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased inflammation of the colon and decreased butyrate production

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased inflammation of the colon and increased butyrate production

options.label: C
options.text: No change in the gut microbiome

options.label: D
options.text: Increased diversity of gut bacteria but decreased butyrate production
